Five-Year Accident History 
The Monterey One Water Treatment Plant has had no CalARP-applicable releases associated with the chlorine injection system in the past five (5) years.

Emergency Response Program
Monterey One Water is a responding facility and will actively respond to releases of chlorine. The facility has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) which includes procedures for evacuation, notification of the public and local first responders, procedures for response to chlorine releases, and information on first aid in the case of exposure.
Monterey One Water has submitted a Hazardous Materials Business Plan and implements coordination with the local emergency planning and response agencies for ERP exercises to ensure that in an event of an emergency they are properly prepared and have knowledge of the system.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The April 1st, 2024 PHA has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 2024 PHA Report. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by October 1st, 2026. The facility has also conducted a Seismic Assessment in 2021, to test for facility integrity of external events. The results of the Seismic Assessment were documented in a formal report to attest the integrity of the facility.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release.  The facility has chlorine detectors that are designed to shut down operations when a concentration of chlorine is reached.

Accidental Release Prevention Program 
As part of the implementation of the CalARP/EPA RMP Program for the Chlorination System, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Monterey One Water to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine for water treatment.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facilitys maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 52,000 lbs. Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 2,500-lbs. threshold for EPA RMP, the 1,500-lbs. threshold for Cal/OSHA PSM and the 100-lbs. state threshold for the CalARP Program.  As a result, the chlorine covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

Accidental Release Prevention Policies
Monterey One Water has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Sewage Treatment System. Monterey One Water's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 
Chlorine is injected into the sewage treatment system in order to disinfect it. The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 52,000 pounds of chlorine kept in twenty-six (26) one-ton containers. Chlorine leak detection and warning is provided by high and low chlorine sensor alarms to control room with an audible and visual alarm system. 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis 
The Off-site Consequence Analysis must be reviewed every five (5) years or within six (6) months of process changes or other changes that may significantly affect the results of the Off-Site Consequence Analysis.
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Per the CalARP Regulations, one (1) worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Sewage Treatment System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  
Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Per the CalARP Regulations, one (1) alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Sewage Treatment System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, Monterey One Water has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.
